well in simple terms it's a radio that you plug into your computer so this is a software defined radio you
can buy one on Amazon for I think about 30 U.S it might be more here um
but they're not super expensive they're very accessible and you plug them into your computer you got a place for an
antenna on the back and all the data antenna picks up gets shoved down your USB port to your
computer and the most important feature especially when you're bringing these things through uh security at the
airport is that you label them properly
a software-defined radio is a regular radio but with less stuff so like these two radios I have here there's a HF rig
from Kenwood and there's a cheap baofang handheld like uh I have right here in a little HT
these radios like this one I have right here in my hand has a whole bunch of circuitry for receiving signals amplifying signals
tuning to a particular frequency and then decoding what it receives whether it's demodulating the am or FM or
sideband Transmissions or getting the data out of or whatever there's circuitry to do all this stuff
and in the case of this little radio here this this baofang I think this is about the same price as a software
defined radio but it's fairly limited and it doesn't have much range and it's kind of fragile honestly it's a little
cheap but they're a great way to get started um but it's got all this extra circuitry in
it that's all about decoding and demodulating a software defined radio
doesn't have any of that stuff it has circuitry to tune and to say how much
bandwidth you want to consume and it's got circuitry to bring that single in and amplify it adjust the gain
but that's it it just samples a swath of the spectrum and shoves it down a USB
port and then software can take that sample of just whatever's coming in from the
Spectrum and decode it or demodulate it or both
and so the software does the heavy lifting and all the software is free and so this means software defined radios are cheap
they're much cheaper than a traditional radio and then but they're also very powerful because you can do all sorts of things

reporting system it's a who all here remembers or is it familiar
with x25 the networking protocol a couple of you most of you are like that's way down in
the bottom of the OSI model I don't care what you think about it but so in ham radio you have ax25 which stands for
amateur x25 and it sends radio packets you can do TCP over radio
packet-based radio it's slow it's very slow it's 1200 baud
so it's really really slow well people would create TCP connections
Little TCP networks over radio but it kind of worked okay but packet collisions was kind of the pain in the
butt and everyone could hear everything aprs is sort of an extension of that idea that's simplified where people just
sort of shout out information about their location or whatever over these packets instead and so it kind of looks
like this so you've got various people out there that have Associated aprs device broadcasting say their location
from their vehicle and so you'll see people on little Maps actually you can look at the map and see where they're at
and figure out who's speeding actually but they can um this these packets they
all have their geolocation they've got latitude and longitude as part of their data and so Vehicles will Hames will do
this to track their vehicles there are various weather stations that will people will mount on their houses
and these weather stations will give their latitude and longitude and every 20 minutes broadcast the current weather
conditions at that location and these this is an aprs packet that can be broadcast and if you're in the area you
can pick it up and hear what their learn what the weather is nearby
and actually even individuals with handheld radios or base stations can broadcast aprs packets and address them
to other users other ham radio operators using their call sign
and you can do sort of like a text messaging back and forth over radio all these are broadcast out
and they can be picked up by individual stations so like I could just listen to them and decode them
they're often picked up by repeaters and so uh someone will hear it and then it will rebroadcast it changing
the Header information and send it out again so it goes to another station and they can hop a couple times
and so this this by this way if I can see a repeater I can from my handheld radio I could send a signal to them and
then it can get out to like the entire state in the United like in this entire state of Ohio where I live
even though like a little handheld radio like this has a range of maybe five miles
that'd be what 10 kilometers roughly
and some of those repeaters are internet gateways and this is where aprs is really neat because it's not only
a uh radio thing it's also an internet thing so these internet gateways will receive these packets send them into a
whole cluster of servers on the Internet run by all the hobbyists that maintain this network
and then there are Gateway programs where they can route it to software on the internet so for example there is a a
weather bot you can send a message from yourself to wxbot over radio it would be
picked up by a repeater and repeated a couple times the Gateway will send it in and then it will go to a piece of
software that will get the weather for whatever location you ask for then it will generate new packets the
Gateway will send the packet back out it'll go through the network again and then you'll receive it back on your radio uh you know like a minute later
